headline: Bright and Fruity Strawberry Jam, Your Way Recipe
description: This classic strawberry jam is built on a very basic formula. Follow it and you'll have a jam that comes together quickly and ends up bright and fruity. Or, use the formula to your advantage, making substitutions that are guaranteed to work.
name: Bright and Fruity Strawberry Jam, Your Way Recipe
keywords: condiment, fruit, Jam, preserve, science of preservation
recipeIngredient: 4 cups (22 ounces; 625g) roughly chopped hulled strawberries (see note)
2 tablespoons (30ml) fresh juice from 1 lemon, plus more if needed
1/3 cup powdered low-sugar pectin (1 1/2 ounces; 45g), such as Ball or Sure-Jell, plus more if needed (see note)

recipeInstructions.text: Combine strawberries and lemon juice in a large nonreactive saucepan and set over medium heat until simmering. Stir in sugar and bring mixture to a full boil over medium-high heat, then reduce to a simmer. Stir in pectin until dissolved, return heat to medium-high and bring to a full rolling boil. As soon as mixture reaches a full boil, cook for 1 minute, then remove from heat. Let stand 5 minutes.

To Check the Jam Set: Spoon 1 tablespoon (15ml) jam onto a small dish and allow to cool completely, to room temperature. Run a finger through the jam. If the jam remains separated, it is properly set; if it runs back together, it is not. If not set, add an extra 1 tablespoon lemon juice and 1 tablespoon low-sugar pectin, then return to a boil and boil for 1 minute longer. Repeat jam set test until jam is properly set.

Carefully scrape any foam or scum from surface of jam. Transfer jam to clean jars, leaving 1/4 inch space at the top; seal jars. Jam can be refrigerated for up to 3 weeks or frozen for up to 3 months. If heat-processing the jam, process for 8 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Wow. I subbed in lime juice, because I had a couple limes laying around, and I also used an erythritol/monk fruit sweetener. The jam came out amazing. I'm never buying the store bought sugar free jam again! Thank you so much!

made the recipe today, with strawberries from my garden. It set up perfectly. thanks so much. Perfect for a small bunch of fruit. It is a little tarter than I like, but still good. Can I omit the lemon juice?
You metion this recipe will make 6 to 8 'jars' of jam, but you never say what size the jars are. 6oz; 8oz; 16 oz ?????

If one is trying to cut back on sugar a bit, would it be OK to use half sugar / half Stevia in this recipe? I realize that Stevia has a "taste" that will be noticeable, but do you know if it would work chemically-speaking; i.e., causing it to gel too much or too little, or affecting the shelf life, etc?

Yeah, just stopped in the middle of this "comment" to scan the article I just discovered below; didn't see anything about artificial sweeteners, but it seems like the low-sugar pectin would be quite important! Perhaps further reducing the sugar would be a step too far...?

Thanks! :)
(Strawberry jam is my favorite! I spread it on pancakes because I loathe maple syrup.)
.

@Maggie714- Congratulations on making your first batch of jam. One of the alchemical elements to jam-making is the "ish" factor of the total output. A survey of recipes (from legit sources) will always note that there will be variance in the output due to the composition of the fruit. 

To answer your specific question: If after cooking the berries they seem to be releasing a lot of liquid (a sign of super-ripe, maybe overripe berries) and want to increase the berry to liquid ratio; you can add one more cup of clean and cut berries without increasing the sugar and pectin. Do add a teaspoon of lemon juice. BUT those berries will also release liquid, so you may be chasing your proverbial tail!

Something I do if the berries I'm working with are extra juicy--mash them all together for a pulpy strawberry jam vs. a jam with larger chunks of strawberries. 

Without knowing your exact steps, I'm going to offer a couple of troubleshooting questions that can also affect the output.
-Did you measure the strawberries after you cleaned and cut them? Volumetric measuring can be hinky, but it's the most common method used for small fruit. (Weight measures are tricky because of the variance between fruits; ie: apples vs. raspberries. Though a pound is a pound; a pound of apples is much less in total volume than a pound of raspberries.)For the best results, measure the base 4-cup / 1-quart amount after cleaning and cutting berries into smallish uniform pieces.

-If you notice the strawberries are releasing a lot of juice during the first cooking period, keep them on the heat a bit longer (prior to adding lemon juice, sugar, and pectin), while stirring to prevent scorching to allow the extra liquid to cook off. Proceed to the next steps when the berry to liquid ratio is more suitable to your tastes.

item.name: Bright and Fruity Strawberry Jam, Your Way Recipe
